key_insight: GateFusion introduces a Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder that enables fine-grained, layer-wise cross-modal interactions between pretrained audio and visual encoders, improving active speaker detection by adaptively selecting and combining complementary cues.
problem_solved: Late fusion methods miss subtle, time- and space-varying audioâ€“visual correlations needed to reliably identify who is speaking in unconstrained video; GateFusion addresses this by enabling hierarchical, gated cross-modal integration.
method: Use strong pretrained unimodal encoders for audio and visual streams to extract robust per-frame features.
Introduce a Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder (HiGat) that applies learned gating at multiple levels to selectively fuse audio and visual features and capture fine-grained interactions.
Perform cross-modal attention and gated residual connections across hierarchy levels to adaptively emphasize the most relevant modality cues for each frame.
impact: Provides a practical, plug-and-play fusion module that boosts robustness of ASD in real-world, noisy, and multi-speaker settings; useful for practitioners building multimodal perception systems requiring precise temporal alignment and modality-specific uncertainty handling.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: pretrained audio & visual encoders feeding into the Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder with gated connections highlighted.
Layered block diagram: multiple fusion stages showing per-level gates turning features on/off (illustrate hierarchical gating).
Qualitative video-frame examples: before/after fusion showing corrected active speaker detections in challenging scenarios (occlusion, noise, overlapping speech).
Bar/line chart: comparative performance (e.g., precision/recall or AUC) of late-fusion baseline vs. GateFusion across realistic datasets.
paper_title: GateFusion: Hierarchical Gated Cross-Modal Fusion for Active Speaker Detection
paper_authors: Yu Wang, Juhyung Ha, Frangil M. Ramirez, Yuchen Wang, David J. Crandall
